Introduction

Bariatric surgery encompasses a group of surgical procedures designed to promote sustained weight loss and improve obesity-related comorbidities by modifying the gastrointestinal anatomy and physiology.  It is the most effective long-term treatment for severe (morbid) obesity when conservative measures (eg, diet, exercise, pharmacotherapy) are unsuccessful.  In addition to facilitating significant and durable weight reduction, bariatric surgery improves metabolic health, reduces cardiovascular risk, and enhances overall quality of life.

Benefits



Bariatric surgery provides numerous benefits, including:



  • Sustained weight loss:  Produces more durable weight loss than nonsurgical interventions.  On average, patients lose 20%-35% of baseline body weight, with maintenance for many years.
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus remission:  Leads to significant improvement in glycemic control, and, in many cases, complete remission of diabetes mellitus.
  • Cardiovascular risk reduction:  Lowers the incidence of hypertension, dyslipidemia, myocardial infarction, and stroke, thereby improving long-term cardiovascular outcomes.
  • Improved quality of life:  Enhances mobility, functional capacity, and psychological well-being, and often reduces dependence on medication.
  • Reduced long-term mortality:  Associated with a significant decrease in all-cause and obesity-related mortality, particularly from cardiovascular disease and diabetes mellitusâ€“related complications.

Indications



Bariatric surgery is recommended for patients meeting the following criteria:



  • BMI â‰¥35 kg/m2 regardless of obesity-related comorbidities.
  • BMI 30-34.9 kg/m2 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • BMI 30-34.9 kg/m2 and unable to achieve sustainable weight loss or improvement in obesity-related conditions (eg, metabolic syndrome, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, metabolic dysfunctionâ€“associated steatohepatitis, osteoarthritis, urinary incontinence).

Contraindications



Contraindications to bariatric surgery include:



  • Untreated psychiatric disorders or active substance use disorder.
  • Uncontrolled eating disorders (eg, bulimia nervosa).
  • Severe cardiopulmonary or systemic (eg, coagulopathy) disease that prohibits anesthesia/surgery.
  • Active malignancy.
  • Pregnancy (absolute contraindication at the time of surgery).
  • Inability to comprehend or adhere to postoperative lifestyle changes or unrealistic expectations regarding surgical outcomes.


Age alone is not a contraindication to bariatric surgery.  There is no strict upper age limit, although risks increase with comorbidities and frailty.  In pediatric populations, surgery may be appropriate for children and adolescents with a BMI >120% of the 95th percentile for age and sex with a major obesity-related comorbidity or for those with a BMI >140% of the 95th percentile regardless of comorbidities.

Mechanisms of action



The effects of bariatric surgery result from a combination of anatomic, hormonal, and metabolic changes that promote sustained weight loss and improved metabolic health.  Major mechanisms include:



  • Restriction:  Surgical reduction in stomach size limits caloric intake and promotes early satiety.
  • Malabsorption:  In procedures that bypass portions of the small intestine, nutrient absorption is reduced, contributing to caloric deficit and metabolic changes.
  • Hormone regulation:  Rapid delivery of nutrients to the distal small intestine increases secretion of gut hormones such as glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and peptide YY (PYY), which enhance satiety, insulin sensitivity, and glycemic control.
  • Altered gut microbiota:  Bariatric surgery modifies the composition and metabolic activity of the gut microbiome, which may further influence energy metabolism, inflammation, and gut hormone signaling.

Common types of bariatric surgery

Sleeve gastrectomy



Sleeve gastrectomy involves a partial gastrectomy that removes approximately 75%-80% of the stomach, including most of the greater curvature, while preserving the pylorus (

figure 1
).  The small tubular stomach significantly reduces gastric capacity and limits caloric intake, and resection of the fundus removes the majority of ghrelin-producing cells, thereby lowering hunger signals (
figure 2
).  In addition, increased secretion of GLP-1 and PYY promote appetite suppression and improved glycemic control.  Patients typically achieve an average loss of 25%-30% of baseline body weight within 2 years.

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass



Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) involves creating a small gastric pouch that is anastomosed to the jejunum, creating an alimentary limb and a biliopancreatic limb, which carries digestive juices from the bypassed stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum.  These limbs join distally at the common limb, where digestion and absorption occur (

figure 3
).  The small gastric pouch limits food intake and, by bypassing the duodenum and proximal jejunum, reduces nutrient and caloric absorption, contributing to weight loss.



Other bariatric procedures (eg, one-anastomosis gastric bypass, biliopancreatic diversion with or without duodenal switch, gastric banding (

figure 4
)) are performed less commonly due to either lower efficacy or higher complication rates.

Early complications



Early complications (â‰¤30 days postoperatively) include hemorrhage, wound infection, and venous thromboembolism (eg, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolus), as well as the following procedure-specific problems:



  • Anastomotic/staple line leak:  Among the most dangerous complications.  Leaks typically occur within days of surgery due to tension or ischemia at the gastrojejunal or jejunojejunal anastomosis (RYGB) or the staple line (sleeve gastrectomy).  Symptoms may be insidious and include fever, tachycardia , tachypnea, and persistent abdominal pain.  Diagnosis is confirmed with CT scan with oral and intravenous (IV) contrast or during intraoperative exploration.  Aggressive management with fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and either endoscopic or surgical repair is required to prevent sepsis and death.
  • Bowel ischemia:  May result from mesenteric ischemia, kinking/edema at the jejunojejunostomy, or, rarely, early internal hernia (small intestine herniates through a surgical defect in the mesentery).  It presents with severe abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, and sometimes minimal peritoneal signs.  Diagnosis is with CT scan with IV contrast, and treatment is with urgent surgical exploration.

Late complications



Late complications (>30 days postoperatively) of bariatric surgery may develop.

General complications



  • Anastomotic stricture/stenosis:  Usually develops within the first year after surgery due to ischemia, ulceration, or fibrosis at the anastomosis.  Progressive narrowing causes outflow obstruction with nausea, postprandial vomiting, reflux, and dysphagia, sometimes even to liquids.  Diagnosis is confirmed by upper endoscopy and treatment involves endoscopic balloon dilation.
  • Cholelithiasis:  Occurs in 30%-40% of patients after rapid weight loss (especially with malabsorptive procedures such as RYGB).  Mechanisms include altered bile composition (eg, cholesterol supersaturation), which promotes stone precipitation, and gallbladder stasis/dysmotility due to decreased cholecystokinin, which is normally secreted by the duodenum.  Ursodeoxycholic acid prophylaxis for 6 months postoperatively may reduce risk, and cholecystectomy may be required if symptoms develop.
  • Small bowel obstruction:  May result from internal hernia, postoperative adhesions, or ventral/incisional hernia.  It causes colicky abdominal pain, abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting.  CT scan confirms the diagnosis.  Surgical intervention may be required if ischemia is suspected.

Roux-en-Y complications



  • Marginal ulcer (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  Most often develops at the gastrojejunal anastomosis and presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, GI bleeding (eg, melena, hematemesis), or obstructive symptoms.  Marginal ulcers can occur in the early postoperative period due to tissue ischemia but are more likely to develop months to years after surgery due to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use and/or smoking.  Ulcers are diagnosed on endoscopy and managed with proton pump inhibitor therapy.  Refractory cases may require surgery.
  • Dumping syndrome (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  When the pyloric sphincter is removed or circumvented, incompletely digested, hyperosmolar food particles enter the small intestine rapidly, causing fluid movement from the intravascular space to the intestinal lumen.  This also causes activation of autonomic (sympathetic) reflexes and the release of vasoactive hormones (eg, vasoactive intestinal peptide).  Clinical manifestations include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, nausea, diaphoresis, flushing, palpitations, hypotension, and tachycardia.  These typically occur within 15-30 minutes after eating (early dumping syndrome).  Postprandial hypoglycemia may also occur several hours after a meal (late dumping syndrome).  Small, frequent meals high in fiber and low in simple sugars can alleviate symptoms.


  • Nutritional deficiencies:  Bypassing the stomach, duodenum, and first portion of the jejunum impairs absorption of iron, B12, folate, calcium, and fat-soluble vitamins, which can lead to significant nutrient deficiencies.  Patients should receive multivitamin supplementation and have periodic nutrient level screening (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ).
  • Recurrent urolithiasis:  Common after gastric bypass due to hyperoxaluria and hypocitraturia.  Fat malabsorption causes free fatty acids to bind calcium, leaving oxalate unbound and more readily absorbed, which increases renal oxalate excretion.  Malabsorption also causes low urinary citrate.  Because citrate inhibits kidney stones, the combined effect of hyperoxaluria and hypocitraturia increases the risk for kidney stones.
  • Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ):  The proximal small intestine normally contains minimal bacterial colonization due to gastric acidity and peristalsis; however, RYGB creates a blind loop of intestine that allows for excessive bacterial growth.  This results in watery diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, flatulence, bloating, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies due to malabsorption.  Symptoms improve with antibiotics, but recurrence is common.

Sleeve gastrectomy complications



  • Acid reflux and Barrett esophagus:  New-onset or worsened reflux is common after sleeve gastrectomy due to increased intragastric pressure and loss of the fundic reservoir.  PPI therapy can be effective, but recalcitrant cases may require conversion to RYGB.

Long-term management



After bariatric surgery, lifelong follow-up and adherence to specific health measures are required to maintain weight loss, prevent complications, and ensure adequate nutrition.  Patients should be counseled on daily vitamin and mineral supplementation, regular physical activity, limiting processed foods, and ongoing participation in behavioral counseling or support groups.  Consistent follow-up is recommended to monitor weight trends, dietary habits, psychosocial well-being, and laboratory parameters (eg, hemoglobin A1c, micronutrient levels).

Summary



Bariatric surgery is the most effective long-term therapy for severe obesity, producing durable weight loss and remission of many obesity-related comorbidities.  By altering the anatomy and physiology of the gastrointestinal tract, these procedures reduce food intake, limit absorption, and promote hormonal changes that regulate appetite, satiety, and glucose metabolism.  Although complications can occur, routine follow-up and adherence to postoperative recommendations can lead to substantial improvements in weight, metabolic health, and overall quality of life.
